"Brain Power is derived from a combination of scores on the following five dimensions. Accuracy: the more winnings completed perfectly, the higher the score Speed: the faster the completion, the higher the score Intensity: the more difficult the puzzle, the higher the score Stamina: the more days you complete Sudoku, the higher the score Explosiveness: the more puzzles completed in a single day, the higher the score"

Please use Cross‚ÄìHatching solve all the number \"8\" on the board.
You have mastered the skills of Cross‚ÄìHatching, use this skill to solve Sudoku faster!

Sudoku cross‚Äìhatching, is where you look at a single box with respect to two other boxes. You search for a specific number and see if that number will fit anywhere within the section you are looking at.
Let‚Äôs focus on number <c1>7</c1> and the <c1>highlighted area</c1>. A single number can not appear twice in the same row, column or box.
Therefore, <c1>7 </c1>can not be filled in the area marked with ‚Äùx‚Äù in <c1>this box</c1>, then there is only one cell left in <c1>this box </c1>that can be filled with <c1>7</c1>.

The easiest way starting a Sudoku puzzle is to scan rows and columns within each triple‚Äìbox area, eliminating numbers or squares and finding situations where only a single number can fit into a single square.
There is an advanced skill to help you become a master!

If two numbers only appear in two cells of a row, column, or block, we define this pair of numbers as a hidden pair. These two cells can only be filled with these two numbers so the other candidate numbers in these two cells can be eliminated.
Let‚Äôs focus on the marked numbers in this box.
In this box, <c1>5</c1> and <c1>9</c1> only appear in <c2>these two cells</c2>, so <c2>these two cells </c2>can only contain <c1>5</c1> and <c1>9</c1>.
Therefore, any number other than<c1> 5 </c1>and <c1>9 </c1>should be deleted from <c2>these two cells</c2>.

If four numbers only appear in four cells of a row, column, or block, and each cell contains two, three, or four of these four numbers, we define this set of numbers as a hidden quadruple, These four cells can only be filled with these four numbers, so the other candidate numbers in these four cellscan be eliminated.

In this row, <c1>2</c1>, <c1>6</c1>, <c1>7</c1> and <c1>8</c1> only appear in <c2>these four cells</c2>, so <c2>these four cells</c2> can only contain <c1>2</c1>, <c1>6</c1>, <c1>7</c1> and <c1>8</c1>.
Therefore, any number other than <c1>2</c1>, <c1>6</c1>, <c1>7</c1> and <c1>8</c1> should be deleted from <c2>these four cells</c2>.
If a cell has more than one candidate, but only that cell contains a certain number in its row, column, or block, then that cell can be directly filled with that number.
This is the only cell containing <c1>6</c1> in this row.

If three numbers only appear in three cells of a row, column, or block, and each cell contains two or three of these three numbers, we define this set of numbers as a hidden triple, These three cells can only be filled with these three numbers, so the other candidate numbers in these three cells can be eliminated.
Let‚Äôs focus on the marked numbers in this column.
In this column, <c1>1</c1>, <c1>5</c1> and <c1>9</c1> only appear in <c2>these three cells</c2>, so <c2>these three cells</c2> can only contain <c1>1</c1>, <c1>5</c1> and <c1>9</c1>.
Therefore, any number other than <c1>1</c1>, <c1>5</c1> and <c1>9</c1> should be deleted from <c2>these three cells</c2>.

Playing brain games like Sudoku can even improve people‚Äôs cognitive abilities.
I love Sudoku because that doesn‚Äôt involve staring at a screen and killing time.
I like to relax after a long day by doing Sudoku. It‚Äôs my meditation.
Tried and tested by generations of solvers, Sudoku is the original brain‚Äìbuilding amuse‚Äìbouche.
Solving Sudoku puzzles eases stress‚Äîand makes you smarter!
It helps me keep my mind active, which I‚Äôve noticed affects my memory about work and stuff.
My dog doesn‚Äôt like it when I bring out the Sudoku, but what can I say? It‚Äôs a favourite.
Playing Sudoku helps you learn how to solve problems by using deductive reasoning.
Having a healthy competitive streak is part of being a great Sudoku player.
The first number puzzles that were similar to modern Sudoku appeared in a French newspaper in 1895
Sudoku requires you to exercise a variety of mental ‚Äúmuscles‚Äù ‚Äì from deductive reasoning to memory.
According to recent mathematics research, Sudoku must with at least 17 clues to have a valid solution
Sudoku requires logical ‚Äúleft brain‚Äù thinking, it requires the ability to make sense of a mishmash of numbers.
My only tip to you, if you‚Äôre wondering about how to find time for Sudoku, is‚Ä¶to schedule it in.
You can‚Äôt go back in time, but you can go forward in time if you do Sudoku.
Solve a puzzle to ignite your daily streak!
Remember that Sudoku is not your ‚Äújob‚Äù ‚Äì if it ever stops being fun, just take a break.
The only way to move forward is to stop looking back!
"Don't always envy others, but forget that you will shine."
When a person through all the suffering, it is not so sad.
"Since you can't use it all at once, don't use your mind when you use it."
No one is more lucky, just more desperate.
Great minds have purpose, others have wishes.
It is impossible to please a man who is indecisive over and over again
Love can withstand the long years, gentleness can block the hard times.
With enough time, you can get used to almost anything.
Your life today is the result of your attitudes and choices in the past.
Life is full of ups and downs. The trick is to enjoy the ups and have courage during the downs.
Wherever you go, whatever you do, I will be right here waiting for you.
Don‚Äôt be discouraged, your good fortune is coming to you.

If a candidate number can only appear in two or three cells of each of four rows or four columns, and these cells are exactly in the same four columns or four rows, then the candidate number can be eliminated from other cells in these four columns or four rows.

First, in these four rows, only <c2>these marked cells</c2> can be filled with <c1>9</c1>. Each row must have a cell filled with <c1>9</c1>, so four of <c2>these cells</c2> must be filled with <c1>9</c1>.
These cells are also restricted in <c1>four columns</c1>, so four of <c2>these cells</c2> in <c1>these four columns</c1> must be filled with <c1>9</c1>. And a number can only appear once in a column.
So <c2>a marked cell</c2> must be filled with <c1>9</c1> ineach of <c1>these four columns</c1>. Then we can delete <c1>9</c1> from other cells in <c1>these four columns</c1>.

"Killer Sudoku is based on the classic Sudoku. The field is divided into irregularly shaped areas(cages)."
The sum of the numbers in the cells of a ‚Äúcage‚Äù need to match the value in the upper left corner.ÔºàThe number in each ‚Äúcage‚Äù is not repeated.Ôºâ
"This cell can be filled with number \"1\". (7‚Äì6 = 1)"
Now we use the rules of classic Sudoku and Killer Sudoku to solve the rest of the puzzle now!
Solving this Killer Sudoku means your IQ is higher than 120!
The sum of the numbers in the cells of a ‚Äúcage‚Äù need to match the value in the upper left corner.ÔºàThe number in each ‚Äúcage‚Äù is not repeated.Ôºâ
In each row, column, and block, only numbers 1‚Äì9 can be filled. When a row, column, or block has already filled in 8 cells the remaining blank cell should be filled with the unique missing number.
So <c1>6 </c1>is the only possible number for<c1> this cell</c1>.
So <c1>1 </c1>is the only possible number for<c1> this cell</c1>.

It is based on finding the missing number. To find the missing number you should take a look at the numbers that are already exist in the 3x3 block you are interested in, and in the rows and columns connected with it.
Let‚Äôs solve <c1>this cell</c1> together. It is shared by a box and a row, and each of them can only contain the numbers 1‚Äì9 without repetition.
Numbers other than <c1>3 </c1>already appear in the box or the row. Therefore, <c1>3 </c1>is the only possible number for <c1>this cell</c1>.

If a candidate number only exists in a row or column within a block, then this candidate number will not appear in other cells that are influenced by the same row or column.
Look, <c2>these cells </c2>are the only cells in this box that may contain<c1> 2</c1>. So one of <c2>these cells</c2> must be filled with <c1>2</c1>.
<c2>These cells </c2>are also restricted in <c1>a single row</c1>. Therefore, i<c1>n this row</c1>, <c1>2 </c1>must be filled in one of <c2>these cells</c2>.
Then <c1>2</c1> should be deleted from other cells in <c1>this row</c1>.

If there are two cells in a row, column, or block that only contain the same two candidate numbers, we define this pair of numbers as a naked pair. These two numbers will not appear in the candidate numbers of other cells in the same row, column, or block. Therefore, we can eliminate these two numbers from the candidate numbers of other cells in that row, column, or block.
Let‚Äôs focus on the marked numbers in this column.
There are <c2>two cells</c2> in this column that share the exact same two candidates (<c1>1 </c1>and <c1>2</c1>), so <c1>1 </c1>and<c1> 2</c1> can only be placed in <c2>these two cells</c2>.
Therefore, we can delete <c1>1 </c1>and <c1>2 </c1>from other cells in the same column.

If four cells in a row, column, or block only contain two, three, or four candidate numbers that are the same, we define this set of numbers as a naked quadruple. These four numbers will not appear in the candidate numbers of other cells in the same row, column, or block.
Let‚Äôs focus on the marked numbers in this row.

There are <c2>four cells</c2> in this row that share the exact same four candidates(<c1>2</c1>, <c1>3</c1>, <c1>6</c1> and <c1>7</c1>), so <c1>2</c1>, <c1>3</c1>, <c1>6</c1> and <c1>7</c1> can only be placed in <c2>these four cells</c2>.
Therefore, we can delete <c1>2</c1>, <c1>3</c1>, <c1>6</c1> and <c1>7</c1> from other cells in the same row.
If a cell only has one candidate remaining then that cell can only be filled with that candidate number.

If three cells in a row, column, or block only contain two or three candidate numbers that are the same, we define this set of numbers as a naked triple. These three numbers will not appear in the candidate numbers of other cells in the same row, column, or block.
Let‚Äôs focus on the marked numbers in this row.
There are<c2> three cells</c2> in this row that share the exact same three candidates(<c1>1</c1>, <c1>2</c1> and <c1>7</c1>), so 1, 2 and only be placed in <c2>these three cells</c2>.
Therefore, we can delete <c1>1</c1>, <c1>2</c1> and <c1>7</c1> from other cells in the same row.

"Rules of Classic Sudoku:
Fill the 9x9 grid so that:
‚Ä¢ Each <#1>3x3</#1> <#1>box</#1> has numbers 1‚Äì9 ‚Ä¢ Every <#2>row</#2> has numbers 1‚Äì9 ‚Ä¢ Every <#3>column</#3> has numbers 1‚Äì9
No repeats in any <#1>3*3</#1> <#1>box</#1>, <#2>row</#2>, or <#3>column</#3>!"

For the mode of 16x16, the rule is the same as other modes except for the alphabets added. The same single number and alphabet may not appear twice in the same row, column, or any of the 4x4 blocks.
If you want to change between the number and alphabets, you could slide the number area.
How do I play 16*16 Sudoku game?

First of all, we feel terribly sorry if any of this situation occurred. If such an advertisement happened, you can first take a screenshot of the inappropriate advertisement and contact us via App‚ÄìSettings‚ÄìFeedback.
What if I saw an inappropriate advertisement or one that cannot be closed? What can I do?

Killer Sudoku and Ice Sudoku are all special Sudoku, which are time‚Äìlimited games that you can find on Homepage. The only difference between Killer Sudoku and classic Sudoku is the existence of a cage, which are shown in dotted lines. For every cage, there is a number on the corner, which is supposed to be the sum for every cell that this cage contains. And your mission is to fill the number that are both following the rule of classical Sudoku and the rule of cage sum. For Ice Sudoku, your job is to crack all the ice cubes in rather limited moves! In order to crack one ice cube, you need to solve the puzzle where the ice is located. You can correctly fill the numbers of all the cells except for the ice cell in one row, one column or one box to successfully break the ice cube.
What are Killer Sudoku and Ice Sudoku games? How to play Killer Sudoku and Ice Sudoku?

Dark mode is available on our setting, which can absolutely help you if you want to play Sudoku games at night. First, you can open a game of any difficulty, and you may find the palette icon in the top right corner of your game screen. When you click it, there will be three different themes, and the third one is the dark mode.
I want to play Sudoku at night, so how can I turn on the dark mode?
To change the difficulty level, you can refer to the steps below:
Tap the New Game button on the Home screen;
How do I change the difficulty level?
You may need to mark notes if you have several possible solutions for later correction.
Tap the Pencil button in the bottom right corner of the screen;
Select a cell that you want to mark notes;
Select all the numbers that you want to enter this cell as notes;
Then, your notes will be presented in the cell as small gray numbers.

Fast Pencil is a tool that you can use during Hard Sudoku games or Expert Sudoku games. It should be noted that the Fast pencil is not available on Easy and Medium level of the Sudoku game. Fast Pencil can be considered as the advanced version of Pencil. The difference between Fast Pencil and Pencil is that Fast Pencil can help you to fill all possible numbers in all cells in one seconds, which can be a great help when you have trouble solving some of the Sudoku puzzles.
What is the Fast Pencil, and what is the function of it?

"If you are in the middle of a game, you could first come back to the homepage of the game with the exit button located at the top right of the game screen. Then you could click the back button of your device. After that, there will be a pop‚Äìup screen asking whether you're going to quit the game. If you could not find the back button on your device, you may try to slide upward in your screen bottom, then the back button can be viewed."
Otherwise you could click your back button on your device directly, it will work as the steps described above.
How do I quit the app?
Currently, we offer the function of \"Remove Ads\" in Settings. The exact steps are as follows.
Tap the gear button in the top right corner of your screen;
Tap Get Premium and SUBSCRIBE, and then follow the instructions there.

"As for the correct answer, at present, all of our questions are set as unique solutions. Sometimes it seems that there is no repetition after entering the numbers, and it seems correct for the time being, but if you continue to solve the puzzle, you will find that you can't fill all the spaces. This will be judged as an error when entering the numbers. And if you don‚Äôt know what step to take next, you can use hints:"
Select a cell whose number you want to know;
Tap the Hint button in the middle right side of the screen;
The correct answer will be given in the selected cell.
I think some of the Sudoku puzzles cannot be solved, and the system rules my answer as wrong.
You could click the \"Personal\" tab at the right bottom to log in with your account first. Then you may find the cycle‚Äìlike blue button beside your name, click it, the synchronization would start.
How do I synchronize my game data?
Currently, we offer three different background themes, which are bright, yellow and dark themes. Also, there different font sizes are provided for your choice. You can follow the steps below:
Tap the palette icon in the top right corner of your game screen;
Three color themes and different font sizes will be presented and you can select your favourite one.
How do I change the background theme? How do I make the font bigger or smaller?

Battle tickets can be used as coupons to enter Sudoku Battle and play against other players in the world! Each regular Sudoku battle will consume one battle ticket. And the count of all your obtained battle tickets will be given in the top left corner in the Battle page.
You can earn battle tickets either by watching one advertisement or by reward.

"In the Row F, the candidate number 8 only appears in the Cell F6 and Cell F9. In the Column 5, the candidate number 8 only appears in the Cell D5 and Cell H5. And the end points F6 and D5 are in the same block. The Cell H9 is intersection in chain of the Cell F9 and H5. So we can delete the candidate number 8 in H9. A 2‚ÄìString Kite is a second special form of Turbot Fish, that can be found in lots of Sudokus. The description: Concentrate again on one digit. Find a row and a column that have only two candidates left (the strings). One candidate from the row and one candidate from the column have to be in the same block. The candidate that sees the two other cells can be eliminated.2‚ÄìString Kites work similar to Skyscrapers: One of the two ends of the strings must be true."

"In the Block 8, the candidate number 2 forms 'T/L/+' chain. The candidate number 2 only appears in the Cell A6, A2 in the Row A. At the same time, the chain in the Block 8 is in the same column with A6. The Cell A5 is intersection in chain of the Cell A2 and the Row H. So we can delete the candidate number 2 in H2. If two lines (e.g., a row and a column) cover all possible places for a given digit in some box, then that digit cannot occur on both lines outside that box, since that would not leave any place for the digit inside the box."

"In the Row H, the candidate number 6 & 8 only appear in Cell H1 & Cell H2, so we can delete other candidate numbers in these two cells. All Hidden Subsets work the same way, the only thing that changes is the number of cells and candidates affected by the move. Take Hidden Pair: If you can find two cells within a house such as that two candidates appear nowhere outside those cells in that house, those two candidates must be placed in the two cells. All other candidates can therefore be eliminated."

"In the Block 4, the candidate number 5,6,7,8 only appear in Cell D1 & Cell D2 & Cell E1 & Cell E2, so we can delete other candidate numbers in these four cells. Hidden Quadruples (4 candidates in 4 cells) are relatively seldom. It is very hard to spot them without using pencil marks."

"Candidate number 9, only appears in the Cell C6 in the Block 2, so this cell can only be filled with 9. Hidden Single means that for a given digit and house only one cell is left to place that digit. The cell itself has more than one candidate left, the correct digit is thus hidden amongst the rest."

"In the Row G, the candidate number 4,7,8 only appear in Cell G2 & Cell G7 & Cell G9, so we can delete other candidate numbers in these three cells. A hidden triple occurs when three cells in a row, column, or block contain the same three numbers, or a subset of those three. The three cells also contain other candidates."

"In the Column 1, the candidate number 6 only appears in the Block 4. So we can delete the candidate number 6 the other cells in Block 4. Intersection removal is a strategy where you can eliminate one candidate from a cell or cells. There are two types of intersection removal: pointing pairs and box/line reduction.You can use Box/Line reduction if a candidate only appears two or three times in a row or column, and those candidates are also all in the same box. When this happens, you know that the candidate MUST occur in that row or column because it can't appear anywhere else there,so it CAN'T occur elsewhere in that box."

"In the Row A, E, F, G, the candidate number 7 only appears in the Column 2, 4, 5, 9. So we can delete the candidate number 5 in the other cells in the Column 2, 4, 5, 9. Jellyfishes work exactly the same way as X‚Äì Wings, just with four base and four cover sets instead of only four."
Here, you can only fill in \"8\".

"In the Row D, the cell D1 & D6 contain only 2 candidate numbers 2,9. So we can delete 2,9 in the Cell D4. If you can find two cells, both in the same house,that have only the same two candidates left, you can eliminate that two candidates from all other cells in that house."

"In the Row B, the candidate number 2,3,6,7 only appear in Cell B4 & Cell B5 & Cell B6 & Cell B7, so we can delete 2,3,6,7 in the other cells in the Row B. Hidden Quadruples (4 candidates in 4 cells) are relatively seldom. It is very hard to spot them without using pencil marks."

"In B6, there is only one candidate number 9, so this cell can only be filled with 9. Naked Single means that in a specific cell only one digit remains possible (the last remaining candidate has no other candidates to hide behind and is thus naked). The digit must then go into that cell."

"In the Row C, the candidate number 2,3,9 only appear in Cell C5 & Cell C6 & Cell C7, so we can delete 2,3,9 in the other cells in the Row C. If you can find three cells, all in the same house, that have only the same three candidates left, you can eliminate that candidates from all other cells in that house. It is important to note that not all cells must contain all three candidates, but there must not be more than three candidates in the three cells all together."

"In the Row B, the candidate number 9 only appears in the Cell B7 and B4. In the Row I, the candidate number 9 only appears in the Cell 17 and 16. The Cell B7 and 17 are in the same column, at the same time, The Cell B4 and 16 are not in the same column. The Cell A6 and G4 are intersection in chain of the Cell B4 and 16. So we can delete the candidate number 9 in the Cell A6 and Cell G4. A Skyscraper is a simple pattern that occurs rather often in Sudokus and can be easily spotted. It is nothing really new: A Skyscraper is a special form of Turbot Fish and it can be seen as two Sashimi X‚ÄìWings.The description of the pattern sounds more complicated than it really is: Concentrate on one digit. Find two rows (or columns) that contain only two candidates for that digit. If two of those candidates are in the same column (or row), one of the other two candidates must be true. All candidates that see both of those cells can therefore be eliminated."

"In the Row C, F, I, the candidate number 5 only appears in the Column 3, 5, 6. So we can delete the candidate number 5 in the other cells in the Column 3, 5, 6. Swordfishes work exactly the same way as X‚Äì Wings, just with three base and three cover sets instead of only two."

"In the Block 1, the candidate number 1 only appears in the Cell C1 and Cell A3. In the Row I, the candidate number 1 only appears in the Cell 11 and Cell 15. And the end points C1 and 11 are in the same column. The Cell A5 is intersection in chain of the Cell A3 and 15. So we can delete the candidate number 1 in A5. A Turbot Fish is an X‚ÄìChain that is exactly four candidates long. Various shapes can be built with such a chain. One of them resembles a fish, which gave the technique its name (look at the right example: draw two lines from the red candidate to the nearest green and blue candidates to see the fish shape)."

"The candidate numbers of the Cell C1 are W, X,Y, Z(3, 2, 7, 1), the candidate numbers of the Cell B2 are W, Z (3, 1) , the candidate numbers of the Cell C4 are X, Z (2, 1), the candidate numbers of the Cell C1 are Y, Z (7, 1). C1 and B2 are in the same block but in different row, C4 and C7 are in the same row but in different block. So we can delete the number of candidates Z(1) in the intersection of the block where the Cell C1 is located and the row where the Cell C4, C7 is located. A WXYZ‚ÄìWing is like an XY‚ÄìWing and an XYZ‚Äì Wing, except it is a group of four cells, one sharing a unit with the other three. The first cell in a WXYZ‚ÄìWing has three or four candidates while the other three, called the wings, have two each. Each of the wings must share one candidate with the first cell, (that's part of sharing a unit) but each wing must share a different value. If the second candidates in the wings are all the same, and are also the same as the leftover candidate of the first cell if the first cell has four candidates, then if any fifth cell shares that candidate and a unit with all the others, that candidate can be eliminated."

"If you exchange the terms rows and columns in the description above, you get an X‚ÄìWing in the columns. Take two rows (the base sets). If you can find two columns, such that all candidates of a specific digit (the fish digit) in both rows are containd in the columns (the cover sets), all fish candidates in the columns that are not part of the rows can be eliminated. The result is called an X‚ÄìWing in the rows. If you exchange the terms rows and columns in the description above, you get an X‚Äì Wing in the columns."

"The candidate 4 has a Two‚Äìstrong‚Äìlink‚Äìmulti‚Äì digit Chain:F1(4) ==(9)‚ÄìA1(9)==(7)‚ÄìC3(7)==3‚Äì 13(3)==4 (Starting Point: Green. End Point: Yellow. Strong‚Äìlink Chain: Solid arrow. Weak link: Dotted line.So we can delete the candidate number 4 in the intersection of F1 and 13. An XY‚ÄìChain is a chain that uses only bivalue cells (similar to Remote Pairs), but the cells can have arbitrary candidates. The only restriction (besides the obvious necessities for the links) is, that the XY‚ÄìChain starts and ends with a strong link on the same digit. As with X‚ÄìChains this proves that one of the endpoints must have that candidate placed, and it can be eliminated from all cells that see both ends of the chain."

"Both the candidate X, Y (9, 7) and the candidate Y, Z (7, 4) are in the Block 4. At the same time, they are not in the same row.Both the candidate X, Y (9,7) and the candidate X, Z (9, 4) are in the same row.At the same time, they are not in the same block.So we can delete Z (4) in the intersection of the block where X, Y (9, 7) is located and the line where X, Z (9, 4) is located.And we can also delete Z (4) in the intersection of the block where X, Z (9, 4) is located and the line where Y, Z (7, 4) is located. An XY‚ÄìWing is really a short XY‚ÄìChain that is described as a pattern and thus can be found more easily. We start by looking for a bivalue cell (the pivot). The possible candidates in that cell are called X and Y. Now we try to find two other cells that see the pivot (the pincers). One of those cells contains candidates X and Z (Z is an arbitrary candidate different from X and Y) and the other candidates Y and Z. Now Z can be eliminated from any cell that sees both pincers."

"The candidate numbers of the Cell 13 are X, Y,Z(5, 7, 9), the candidate numbers of the Cell H3 are Y, Z (7, 9), the candidate numbers of the Cell 19 are X, Z (5, 9). H3 and 13 are in the same block but in different row, 19 and 13 are in the same row but in different block. So we can delete the number of candidates Z(9) in the intersection of the block where the Cell 13 is located and the row where the Cell 19 is located. The XYZ‚ÄìWing is an enhanced version of an XY‚Äì Wing: Now the pivot contains not only candidates X and Y but Z as well. Consequently Z can only be eliminated from cells that see not only the pincers, but the pivot as well."

"The Cells A2 and B5 only contain the candidate number X,Y (1,5) and are not in the same sector. At the same time the candidate number X(1) in Row C only appears in the column of these two cells.So we can delete the candidate number Y (5) in the intersection of A2 and B5. Y‚ÄìWing starts with a square that contains exactly two candidates.This square is sometimes called a pivot or hinge.You can use Y‚ÄìWing if each of the two candidates in the pivot forms a conjugate pair in two different units. The two end points of the conjugate pairs are sometimes referred to as pincers. However, you can only use Y‚ÄìWing if the pincers each contain exactly two numbers, and if one of those two numbers is the same in both pincers. It is this shared number that you might be able to eliminate.Look for squares that both of the pincers can see. If any of these squares contains the shared candidate, you can eliminate that candidate from those squares."

"Traditional Sudoku is a 9√ó9 puzzle grid made up of nine 3√ó3 regions. What you need to do is to complete the Sudoku puzzle and make sure that the same single number may not appear twice in the same row, column, or any of the nine 3√ó3 regions."
Only %1$s of the players solved this puzzle!
Thanks for your feedback, we will read carefully and do better!

If a candidate number can only appear in two or three cells of each of three rows or three columns, and these cells are exactly in the same three columns or three rows, then the candidate number can be eliminated from other cells in these three columns or three rows.

First, in these three columns, only <c2>these marked cells</c2> can be filled with <c1>8</c1>. Each column must have a cell filled with <c1>8</c1>, so three of <c2>these cells</c2> must be filled with <c1>8</c1>.
These cells are also restricted in <c1>three rows</c1>, so three of <c2>these cells</c2> in <c1>these three rows</c1> must be filled with <c1>8</c1>. And a number can only appear once in a row.
So <c2>a marked cell</c2> must be filled with 8 in each of <c1>these three rows</c1>. Then we can delete 8 from other cells in <c1>these three rows</c1>.

Select the digit 3 and check its row.
Since a row can have only one digit 3, other cells in that row cannot be 3.
Each 3x3 box must contain a digit 3, so the last remaining cell in the box must be 3.
Select the highlighted cell and observe the digits already present in its row, column, and box: 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9.
Since each digit can only appear once in its row, column, and box, the only possible digit for this cell is 2.

If a candidate number can only appear in two cells of a row or column, and these two cells are in the same row or column, and if the same candidate number can also only appear in two cells of another row or column, forming a rectangle with the first two cells, then this is called an X‚ÄìWing structure. The candidate number can only appear in the diagonal cells of this rectangle, so the candidate number can be eliminated from other cells in the same row or column as the X‚ÄìWing.
Look, there are two rows having only <c2>two possible cells</c2> for <c1>1</c1> respectively. And they form a rectangle.
We can see that either the group of <c3>green 1</c3> or the group of <c4>red 1</c4> must be filled in.
So either <c2>b5</c2> or <c2>g5</c2> must be <c1>1</c1>, and either <c2>b9</c2> or <c2>g9</c2> must be <c1>1</c1>. Then we can delete <c1>1</c1> from other cells in these two columns.

When three pairs of candidate numbers, consisting of three numbers x, y, and z are formed in three cells, if the xy cell is in the same row, column, or block as the xz and yz cells, then either the xz or yz cell will contain the candidate number z. Therefore the candidate number z can be eliminated from other cells that are controlled by both the xz and yz cells.

Look, there are <c2>two cells</c2> containing <c1>2</c1> and <c3>3</c3>, and <c1>2</c1>, and <c3>8</c3>, respectively. They are in the same row, column or box with <c2>the cell</c2> containing <c3>3</c3> and <c3>8</c3>.
If <c2>i9</c2> is <c3>3</c3>, <c2>g7</c2> must be <c1>2</c1>. lf <c2>i9</c2> is <c3>8</c3>, <c2>a9</c2> must be <c1>2</c1>. Therefore, either <c2>g7</c2> or <c2>a9</c2> must be <c1>2</c1>.
So <c1>2</c1> should be deleted from any of the <c1>intersecting cells</c1> of <c2>g7</c2> and <c2>a9</c2>.

Given three numbers x, y, and z, there are three cells that contain the candidate numbers xz, yz, and xyz. When the cell containing xyz is in the same row/column/block as cells containing xz and yz, one of the cells xz, yz, and xyz must contain the candidate number z. Therefore, any other cells controlled by xz, yz, and xyz can eliminate the candidate number z.

Look, there are <c2>two cells</c2> containing <c3>9</c3> and <c1>5</c1>, and <c3>3</c3> and <c1>5</c1> respectively. They are in the same row, column or box with <c2>the cell</c2> containing <c3>9</c3>, <c3>3</c3>, and <c1>5</c1>.

<c2>g8</c2> can only be filled with <c3>9</c3>, <c3>3</c3> or <c1>5</c1>. lf <c2>g8</c2> is <c3>9</c3>, <c2>i7</c2> must be <c1>5</c1>. lf <c2>g8</c2> is <c3>3</c3>, <c2>g6</c2> must be <c1>5</c1>. Therefore, at least one of <c2>these three cells</c2> must be filled with <c1>5</c1>.
So <c1>5</c1> should be deleted from any of the <c1>intersecting cells</c1> of <c2>g8</c2>, <c2>i7</c2> and <c2>g6</c2>.
